title: 106_s2184
content: The Act titled "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 2000" amends the number and composition of circuits in the United States Code, changing the ninth circuit to include Arizona, California, and Nevada. The "Twelfth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act" changes the number of circuit judges in the ninth and twelfth circuits to 20 and 8 respectively. The "Twelfth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act" reassigns circuit judges from the former ninth circuit to the new ninth and twelfth circuits based on their official station before the effective date of the Act. Senior judges have the option to choose their assignment. SEC. 6. Senior judges from the former ninth circuit can choose to be assigned to the new ninth or twelfth circuit by notifying the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. SEC. 7. Seniority of judges assigned or electing to be assigned will be based on their commission date in the former ninth circuit. SEC. 8. The Act applies to cases. The provisions of this section apply to cases in the former ninth circuit. If a matter has been submitted for decision, further proceedings will continue as if this Act had not been enacted. If a matter has not been submitted, the appeal or proceeding will be transferred to the appropriate court as if this Act had been in effect at the time of the appeal. Proceedings in a case in the former ninth circuit will continue as if this Act had not been enacted. Petitions for rehearing will be treated as though this Act had not been enacted, and if granted, the matter will be reheard by a court as if this Act had not been enacted. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines the former ninth circuit, new ninth circuit, and twelfth circuit. SEC. 10. ADMINISTRATION. The court of appeals for the ninth circuit may take administrative action to implement this Act until July 1, 2002. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2000.
